Mexico Packing List 2025

What to Pack for Every Type of Mexico Trip

Last updated: January 2025

Packing for Mexico depends entirely on where you're going and what you'll be doing. A beach trip to Cancún requires different gear than a cultural exploration of Oaxaca or an adventure in Baja California. This guide gives you customized packing lists for every type of Mexico trip, plus tips on what to leave home.

In This Guide

  • Essential Documents
  • Beach Trip Essentials (Cancún, Tulum, Los Cabos)
  • City Trip Essentials (Mexico City, Oaxaca, Guanajuato)
  • Adventure Trip Essentials (Surfing, Hiking, Diving)
  • Health & Safety Kit
  • Tech & Electronics
  • What NOT to Bring
  • Packing by Season
  • Luggage Tips
  • Destination-Specific Additions

Essential Documents

{<strong>Must-Have Documents:</strong></p><ul><li>Valid passport (at least 6 months validity recommended)</p><ul><li>Printed flight confirmation/itinerary</p><ul><li>Hotel reservations (digital or printed)</p><ul><li>Travel insurance documents</p><ul><li>Credit cards (notify bank of travel)</p><ul><li>Driver's license (if renting a car)</p><ul><li>Copies of all documents (stored separately + cloud backup)</p><p><strong>Digital Essentials:</strong></p><ul><li>Download offline maps (Google Maps or Maps.me)</p><ul><li>Download Uber, DiDi apps</p><ul><li>Save emergency contacts in phone</p><ul><li>WhatsApp (widely used in Mexico)</p><ul><li>Translation app (Google Translate with offline Spanish)}

Beach Trip Essentials (Cancún, Tulum, Los Cabos)

{<strong>Clothing:</strong></p><ul><li>3-4 swimsuits (they take forever to dry in humidity)</p><ul><li>Lightweight cover-ups/sarongs</p><ul><li>Casual shorts and tank tops</p><ul><li>1-2 nice outfits for dinners</p><ul><li>Light sundress or linen pants for restaurants</p><ul><li>Flip-flops for beach</p><ul><li>Comfortable sandals for walking</p><ul><li>Water shoes (for rocky beaches/cenotes)</p><p><strong>Beach Gear:</strong></p><ul><li>Reef-safe sunscreen (regular sunscreen is banned at many cenotes and eco-parks)</p><ul><li>High SPF face sunscreen</p><ul><li>After-sun aloe vera gel</p><ul><li>Wide-brim sun hat</p><ul><li>Quality sunglasses with strap</p><ul><li>Waterproof phone case</p><ul><li>Dry bag for boat trips</p><ul><li>Snorkel gear (optional - easily rented)</p><p><strong>Pro Tip:</strong> Pack light! Laundry is cheap ($1-2/kg) and beach towns are casual. You can buy anything you forget at Walmart or local shops.}

City Trip Essentials (Mexico City, Oaxaca, Guanajuato)

{<strong>Clothing:</strong></p><ul><li>Comfortable walking shoes (cobblestones are uneven)</p><ul><li>Light jacket or cardigan (evenings can be cool, especially at altitude)</p><ul><li>Rain jacket or compact umbrella (June-October rainy season)</p><ul><li>Mix of casual and smart-casual outfits</p><ul><li>Nice outfit for upscale restaurants</p><ul><li>Layers (Mexico City can be 60°F in morning, 80°F at midday)</p><p><strong>City Essentials:</strong></p><ul><li>Crossbody bag or anti-theft backpack</p><ul><li>Portable phone charger</p><ul><li>Comfortable day backpack</p><ul><li>Reusable water bottle</p><ul><li>Hand sanitizer</p><ul><li>Tissues/napkins (not always available)</p><p><strong>For Mexico City specifically:</strong></p><ul><li>Air quality mask (pollution can be bad December-February)</p><ul><li>Light scarf for church visits</p><ul><li>Comfortable shoes that can handle 15,000+ daily steps}

Adventure Trip Essentials (Surfing, Hiking, Diving)

{<strong>Surf Trips (Sayulita, Puerto Escondido):</strong></p><ul><li>Rash guard (sun protection)</p><ul><li>Board shorts/bikini that stays put</p><ul><li>Surf wax (if bringing your own board)</p><ul><li>Waterproof sunscreen</p><ul><li>Basic first aid for reef cuts</p><ul><li>Flip-flops with good grip</p><p><strong>Hiking/Eco-Tours (Copper Canyon, Sierra Norte):</strong></p><ul><li>Hiking boots (broken in!)</p><ul><li>Quick-dry pants/shorts</p><ul><li>Moisture-wicking shirts</p><ul><li>Light rain jacket</p><ul><li>Insect repellent with DEET</p><ul><li>Headlamp</p><ul><li>Reusable water bottle with filter</p><p><strong>Diving/Snorkeling:</strong></p><ul><li>Your own mask (rental masks often leak)</p><ul><li>Reef-safe sunscreen</p><ul><li>Underwater camera</p><ul><li>Dive certification card (if certified)</p><ul><li>Seasickness medication}

Health & Safety Kit

{<strong>Medications:</strong></p><ul><li>Prescription medications (in original containers with prescription)</p><ul><li>Anti-diarrheal (Imodium/Pepto-Bismol)</p><ul><li>Pain relievers (ibuprofen, acetaminophen)</p><ul><li>Antihistamines (for allergies/bug bites)</p><ul><li>Motion sickness medication</p><ul><li>Rehydration salts (for stomach issues)</p><p><strong>First Aid:</strong></p><ul><li>Band-aids and blister pads</p><ul><li>Antibiotic ointment</p><ul><li>Tweezers (for splinters/sea urchin spines)</p><ul><li>Insect bite relief cream</p><ul><li>Small scissors</p><p><strong>Sun/Heat:</strong></p><ul><li>Sunscreen (SPF 30-50)</p><ul><li>Lip balm with SPF</p><ul><li>Aloe vera gel</p><ul><li>Electrolyte packets</p><p><strong>Note:</strong> Pharmacies in Mexico are excellent and most medications are available without prescription. But bring basics to avoid disrupting your trip.}

Tech & Electronics

{<strong>Essential Tech:</strong></p><ul><li>Phone + charger</p><ul><li>Portable battery pack (10,000+ mAh)</p><ul><li>Universal adapter (Mexico uses US-style plugs, but some older buildings have ungrounded outlets)</p><ul><li>Camera + charger + extra memory cards</p><ul><li>E-reader (for beach/pool)</p><ul><li>Noise-canceling headphones (for flights/buses)</p><p><strong>Optional Tech:</strong></p><ul><li>GoPro/action camera (for water activities)</p><ul><li>Drone (check local regulations - prohibited in many areas)</p><ul><li>Laptop (if working remotely)</p><ul><li>International SIM card or Telcel prepaid SIM</p><p><strong>Pro Tip:</strong> WiFi is widely available, but cell coverage can be spotty outside cities. Download offline maps and key info before arrival.}

What NOT to Bring

{<strong>Leave These at Home:</strong></p><ul><li>Expensive jewelry or watches (theft risk, unnecessary)</p><ul><li>Flashy designer bags (draw unwanted attention)</p><ul><li>Too many 'nice' outfits (Mexico is casual)</p><ul><li>Heavy jeans (too hot, pack light pants instead)</p><ul><li>Bulky hair dryers/straighteners (hotels provide, voltage issues)</p><ul><li>More than 2-3 books (buy or trade locally, or use e-reader)</p><ul><li>Excessive cash (ATMs are everywhere, cards widely accepted)</p><p><strong>Items to Buy There Instead:</strong></p><ul><li>Beach hats (cheaper and you won't crush them in luggage)</p><ul><li>Cheap flip-flops (sold everywhere)</p><ul><li>Sunscreen (available at any pharmacy/Walmart)</p><ul><li>Souvenirs/crafts (obviously)</p><ul><li>Mezcal/tequila (at duty-free on way home)}

Packing by Season

{<strong>Dry Season (November-April):</strong></p><ul><li>Lighter packing overall</p><ul><li>Still bring light layers for evenings</p><ul><li>Sun protection essential</p><ul><li>Perfect beach weather gear</p><p><strong>Rainy Season (May-October):</strong></p><ul><li>Compact rain jacket or poncho (essential)</p><ul><li>Quick-dry fabrics</p><ul><li>Waterproof bag for electronics</p><ul><li>Closed-toe shoes that can get wet</p><ul><li>Mosquito repellent (more bugs in rainy season)</p><p><strong>Hurricane Season (June-November, especially August-October):</strong></p><ul><li>Flexible itinerary mindset</p><ul><li>Travel insurance (definitely)</p><ul><li>Backup phone chargers</p><ul><li>Check weather before packing final items}

Luggage Tips

{<strong>Bag Recommendations:</strong></p><ul><li>Carry-on only (if possible) - domestic Mexican flights have stricter weight limits</p><ul><li>Soft-sided bag (easier to stuff in small taxis/shuttles)</p><ul><li>Bright color or distinctive tag (many black bags on carousels)</p><ul><li>TSA-approved lock</p><p><strong>Packing Strategy:</strong></p><ul><li>Roll clothes to save space</p><ul><li>Pack outfit combinations, not individual pieces</p><ul><li>Put heavy items at bottom (near wheels)</p><ul><li>Keep one full outfit in carry-on (lost luggage happens)</p><ul><li>Pack dirty clothes bag</p><p><strong>Weight Limits:</strong></p><ul><li>International flights: Usually 23kg/50lb checked</p><ul><li>Domestic Mexican flights: Often 15-25kg - CHECK YOUR AIRLINE</p><ul><li>Budget airlines (Volaris, Viva): May charge for ALL bags}

Destination-Specific Additions

{<strong>Cancún/Riviera Maya:</strong></p><ul><li>All-inclusive wristband backup (phone photo)</p><ul><li>Water shoes for cenotes</p><ul><li>Light cover-up for Mayan ruins (shoulders covered)</p><p><strong>Mexico City:</strong></p><ul><li>Comfortable walking shoes (non-slip for rainy marble)</p><ul><li>Light jacket for evenings</p><ul><li>Crossbody anti-theft bag</p><p><strong>Oaxaca:</strong></p><ul><li>Layers (altitude = cool mornings)</p><ul><li>Camera for colorful streets</p><ul><li>Cash for markets</p><p><strong>San Miguel de Allende:</strong></p><ul><li>Comfortable shoes for cobblestones</p><ul><li>Elegant casual wear</p><ul><li>Art supplies (if you're an artist - famous for workshops)</p><p><strong>Baja California:</strong></p><ul><li>Binoculars (whale watching)</p><ul><li>Layers (desert = hot days, cold nights)</p><ul><li>Sturdy sandals for beaches}

Frequently Asked Questions

Can I bring prescription medications to Mexico?

Yes, bring medications in original labeled containers with a copy of your prescription. Common medications don't require documentation, but controlled substances (opioids, ADHD meds, etc.) should have written prescriptions. Bring only what you need for your trip length.

Do I need a voltage converter for Mexico?

Mexico uses 127V/60Hz with Type A/B plugs (same as US/Canada). US travelers don't need converters. European/UK travelers need a plug adapter but most modern electronics (phones, laptops) handle 100-240V automatically. Check your charger's label.

Should I pack formal clothes for Mexico?

Mexico is generally casual. One nice outfit for upscale restaurants is enough. Beach towns are very casual (shorts and sandals everywhere). Cities like Mexico City and Guadalajara are slightly dressier but still relaxed by European standards.

How do I pack reef-safe sunscreen?

Look for 'reef-safe' or 'ocean-friendly' labels. Avoid oxybenzone and octinoxate. Brands like Stream2Sea, Raw Elements, and Thinksport are reliable. Note: Many cenotes and eco-parks in Mexico require reef-safe sunscreen or provide their own.
